entry.title: Re: partially committed webservice-transactions in SQL An...
entry.content:
I can't tell what happens within a web procedure when the web client does not wait for the full response, and apparently the web server has no control over this.

As to "partial transactions". There's no such thing in a RDBMS. A transaction either commits or is rolled back, there is no middle ground. (We are not dealing with "nested transactions" aka savepoints, with those, you can roll back savepoints but commit the whole transaction.)

I guess the underlying problem is the behaviour of temporary tables with the NOT TRANSACTIONAL clause: Those do explicitely not follow transactional rules and are not bound to transaction scopes, so the INSERT may take place without an additional UPDATE - and without being rolled back by a rollback statement .

I even noticed that LOAD TABLE into a temporary tables with the NOT TRANSACTIONAL may insert some rows and stop when further rows would lead to errors, so in that context a single LOAD TABLE statement might be not even atomic. I'd asked for that a while ago - but won't take the effort to search this within this sub-optimal platform. ðŸ˜•

To add: I guess I remember that a web service procedure stops the execution once the final SELECT statement is executed, so following statements will not be executed. This is probably something that Mark Culp has explained in detail.

In your case this would be an non-issue as the SELECT is the final statement, so just as a possible helpful hint. (I would probably had put the check for successful execution naively after the SELECT, and that might get lost then...)

entry.title: EBRR Currency Conversion with Spot Rate in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Co-Authored by Stefan Walz and  Gabi Hoffmann

Welcome to this blog, in which we will show the new currency conversion in Event-Based Revenue Recognition. The new revenue recognition method will use a spot rate approach for EBRR postings instead of using a fixed exchange rate. In addition to these enhancements, we offer supplementary options for plan sources. The screenshots are taken from an SAP S/4HANA Cloud CE2508 system; the described functionality is only available in public cloud.

This functionality is based on the professional service tailored customer project scenario using fixed price billing with a cost-based POC.

We will start in this blog with a functional overview. Then we will show an end-to end process in the system based on the professional service tailored customer project scenario. We will close with insights into the EBRR configuration.

 

1.    Motivation and functional scope 

With release 2508, we have delivered a new revenue recognition method, with which the currency conversion is carried out using the rate of the period in which the confirmation/revenue realization takes place.

The method is particularly relevant when the exchange rate continuously and significantly changes in one direction during the project duration. In addition, we support with this method IFRS and US GAAP requirements.

Compared to the existing revenue recognition key SPFC, the new method involves a significantly more complex value determination. This additional complexity can increase the effort required to trace and understand the resulting accounting entries.

The currency conversion method linked to the default key SPFC â€” which continues to use the frozen exchange rate from the time the billing WBS element was created â€” remains fully supported.

Before switching to the new key, we recommend carefully evaluating the benefits and drawbacks of both approaches. While the new method may offer advantages in cases of significant, directional exchange rate fluctuations, it also introduces additional complexity that should be considered when assessing transparency and operational effort.

Motivation for the new EBRR currency method

To get an idea, how the old and new key/method work, we will look at an example. For that we assume a situation where the Euro continuously loses value against the GBP.

The table below shows a comparison of the different keys over a timeframe of 5 months. The project is set up with a project currency in GBP, with a GB customer, with a billing plan amount of 100,000 GBP. The project is assigned to a company code that uses EUR as company code currency.

Figure 1: comparison SPFC - SPFCFX

Both EBRR keys start by using the exchange rate valid at the beginning of the first posting period â€“ 1:1. However, differences become noticeable in period 5. The SPFC key, which uses a frozen rate, determines the exchange rate based on the billing WBS elementâ€™s creation date â€“ 1:1. In contrast, the new key applies the exchange rate from the first day of the current posting period â€“ 1:1,3. Thus, in period 5 for the recognized revenue of the period, 10.000 Â£, the new key uses the current exchange rate of 1:1.3. This results in realized revenue and WIP of 13.000 â‚¬â€”compared to 10.000 â‚¬ realized with the SPFC key.

The new key does not revalue the WIP from previous periodsâ€” in our example, the WIP of 10.000 â‚¬ in period 1 remains unchanged. The current exchange rate of 1:1.3 is applied only to the realized revenue and WIP in period 5. This approach aligns with IFRS and US GAAP requirements.

To revalue the entire WIP using the current rate, the Advanced Foreign Currency Valuation (AFCV) could be applied.

Figure 2 : AFCV (advanced foreign currency run)

Features and Principles of the New Revenue Recognition and Currency Method

The new Event-Based Revenue Recognition (EBRR) method and its currency handling bring significant changes in how revenue is recognized and translated. Hereâ€™s an overview of the key features:

Generally, the project currency is used as transaction currency in ACDOCA for the EBRR postings.

Percentage of Completion Calculated in Company Code Currency

The Percentage of Completion (POC) is calculated in the company code currency. This resulting percentage is then applied to the transaction currency to determine the recognized revenue.

  • Actuals are derived from ACDOCA journal entries.
  • The determination of plan and EAC costs in company code currency depends on the plan source. For example, when reading CPM resource plan costs (source 305), the plan costs are converted using the exchange rate of the respective period.

Consistent Currency Translation Date Within the Reporting Period

For EBRR, the currency conversion date is set to the first day of the reporting period. This ensures that realized revenue is consistent and comparable within the same period.

All EBRR journal entriesâ€”whether posted in real time or during the period-end runâ€”use this date as the exchange rate reference.

General ledger postings such as billing continue to use a daily (M) exchange rate. 

Handling Currency Effects and Valuation of Work in Progress (WIP)

Currency effects arise from the difference between realized and billed revenue. These effects are explicitly shown and posted only at period-end when deferred and accrued (WIP) amounts need to be netted. WIP netting is performed using the FIFO method.

  •             With this we ensure that the remaining WIP is valuated with most current currency rate. 

For updating WIP with current rate use AFCV

Since only the revenue realized in the period is translated using the current rate, the WIP from previous periods needs to be revalued through AFCV. 

Solution approach

With the 2508 release, SAP introduces important enhancements for revenue recognition in fixed price customer projects using cost-based percentage of completion (POC). 

A new revenue recognition key, SPFCFX, is now available. This key uses revenue recognition method 25, which is linked to foreign currency method 28. The key feature of this method is that the currency logic is hardcoded and cannot be adjusted. As a result, the standard foreign currency method (typically left blank or â€˜spaceâ€™) defined at company code level is ignored when using SPFCFX. 

In addition, a new SSCUI has been introduced to extend the scope for selecting plan sources. For the new currency method, by default, plan source 305 is delivered. 

Another innovation in this release: for the first time, it's possible to work with manual plan data in CPM projects. This opens new flexibility for customers who prefer to manage planning manually rather than relying solely on system-generated data. The following example illustrates how the new manual plan source can be used in practice. 

This new currency method in EBRR is not applicable to other methods like Completed Contract, Periodic Revenue Recognition, or Time and Expense Billing.

 

2. System walkthrough with new rev rec key 

Now, letâ€™s look in the system at how the new revenue recognition impacts EBRR calculation and journal entries.

We have chosen a simple example to keep the focus on explaining the new foreign currency method.

In our example, the project currency is GBP, the company code currency is EUR, and the global currency is USD. Throughout this blog series, we will take a closer look at the currency conversion from GBP to EUR, and the procedure shown can then be applied to global currency scenarios as well.

Plan source 500 is assigned to the project, which means that plan data must be uploaded manually.

How to upload plan data â€” and how changes to that plan data interact with the new foreign currency method â€” will be explained in Section 4 of this blog.

Figure 3 : CPM Project in foreign currency

For the manually uploaded plan data, an initial exchange rate of 1:1 was maintained. The plan data is converted using the exchange rate maintained under exchange rate type â€˜Pâ€™. Below is a snapshot of the exchange rates applicable in May:

Figure 4 : Currency exchange rates type 'P''

For this project, costs of 10,000 GBP, converted to 10.000â‚¬ and revenue of 12,000 GBP were uploaded as plan data. The transaction currency corresponds to the projectâ€™s currency, so no conversion in EBRR is needed for the plan revenues â€“ 12,000GBP are taken. For the POC calculation EBRR will take the 10.000â‚¬ as plan costs/EAC.

Figure 5 : Project Plan/Actuals

In the next step, the planned Platinum Consultant from Service Organization 1010 posts time to the project. 10 hours were recorded at a cost rate of 100 EUR/hour, resulting in costs of 1.000 EUR. This results in a POC of 10%. The POC of 10% is multiplied with the planned revenue of 12,000 GBP, to get realized revenue of 1,200 GBP.

Figure 6 : Exchange rates type 'M' for May

To analyze the posted currency amounts in detail, we use the â€˜Display Line Items â€“ Margin Analysisâ€™ report.

Figure 7: first time confirmation in May

In these journal entry items the initial 1:1 exchange rate is reflected.

We have also included the object currency in the report. As you can see, the object currency is aligned with the project currency (GBP). The object currency plays an important role in the new functionality, as it ensures a consistent currency is used for costs, EBRR postings and revenue throughout the process. It also serves as the basis for calculation during period-end closing. Weâ€™ll come back to this point later in the blog.

In the EBRR period-end closing for May no adjustments are posted. So, we move on to the next step:

A second time confirmation for June, along with the creation of the first customer invoice. Both the time confirmation and the billing are executed on the same day â€“ June 17.

However, these transactions will generate postings with different exchange rates, depending on the currencies involved and the timing of each posting.

Therefore, weâ€™ll start with an overview of the exchange rates used.

Figure 8 : Exchange rates type 'M' for June

Again, the consultant reports 10 hours, and the planned data, cost rate, and price remain unchanged. Therefore, the same POC is calculated as with the first-time recording.

However, due to the way exchange rates are maintained, different exchange rates are applied to each posting, hereâ€™s how it looks in the system.

Figure 9 : second time confirmation in June

The new currency conversion method uses the first day of the posting period as the exchange rate date for converting GBP to EUR; on June 1st, the exchange rate was maintained at 1:1,1. This time, the revenue value differs due to the exchange rate applied, resulting in a value of 1.320 EUR.

In the object currency of the cost posting, the usage of the monthly 'M' rate can be observed: the cost posted in EUR with 1.000â‚¬ is converted by 1:1,1 to 909,09 GBP.

The next step is to execute the first billing for the project. It was agreed that an amount of 1,500 GBP should be invoiced on June 17. The created journal entries we analyze here:

Figure 10 : Billing in June

The invoice uses the invoice date to determine the exchange rate and applies the daily 'M' rate, which results in 1,500 GBP * 1,2 = 1.800 EUR.

Weâ€™re moving into period-end closing. Accrued revenue is higher than deferred, and postings were made with different exchange rates â€” something to keep in mind.

Hereâ€™s a snapshot of whatâ€™s been booked so far:

Figure 11: G/L account posting overview

The period-end closing still nets the balance sheet accounts as before â€” but now it also calculates currency effects based on the exchange rate differences.

Hereâ€™s what the closing entries look like this time:

Figure 12 : EBRR period end June with currency effect

You can see that the deferred revenue account was cleared, there was a WIP reduction, and a separate posting for currency effects was created.

Letâ€™s break it down:

  • Thereâ€™s an invoice for 1,500 GBP.
  • Two-time recordings exist:
  • 1,200 GBP from May
  • 1,200 GBP from June
    â†’ Total time recorded: 2,400 GBP

Since time recorded exceeds the invoice amount, we can reduce deferred revenue by reducing accrued revenue (WIP).

The reduction now follows the FIFO principle â€“ first in, first out.

  1. The May time entry (1,200 GBP) was booked at a 1:1 exchange rate.
    â†’ This full amount is used: 1,200 GBP â†’ 1.200 EUR
  1. That leaves 300 GBP to be covered.
    This comes from the June time entry, booked at a 1:1,1 rate.
    â†’ 300 GBP â†’ 330 EUR

This leads to a WIP reduction of 1,500 GBP, calculated as 1.200 EUR (from the first-time entry) plus 330 EUR (from the second) â€” totaling 1.530 EUR.

Now, currency effects are calculated at Company Code currency level:

  • Deferred revenue: 1.800 EUR
  • Accrued revenue: 1.530 EUR
  • Currency effect: 270 EUR

The currency effect is posted using a dedicated SLALI-type 8201. This ensures full transparency â€” allowing you to report on currency effects at any time.

The same logic is applied in Group Currency â€” based on the respective exchange rates used in the original postings.

Another important aspect to understand is how the new functionality behaves when the status â€˜Completedâ€™ (TECO) is set before all WIP is cleared.

In our case, thatâ€™s 900 GBP, which corresponds to 990 EUR and 1,188 USD.

The â€˜Completedâ€™ status is set on July 29, which means the period-end closing for July must be executed to automatically release all remaining WIP.

And this is what the postings look like:

Figure 13 : EBRR period end July / posting date view

At first glance, nothing seems unusual â€” the system posts one line to accrued revenue and another to the revenue adjustment account.

Whatâ€™s new, however, is that it's now much more meaningful to view the postings from an account perspective at the project level.

Figure 14 : EBRR period end July- G/L account view

In the overview, you can see that currency effects are not reversed when the project is completed.

Previously, once a project was completed, the billed revenue reflected the total revenue earned from the project. That was the full story.

With the new currency handling exchange rate differences are now recognized separately on the currency effect account.

As a result, itâ€™s no longer enough to look at billed revenue alone. To get the full revenue picture, you now need to combine billed revenue and revenue adjustment, offset by the amount on the currency effects account.

 

3. EBRR revenue recognition at period-end in specific situations

The period-end closing with the new key now delivers the currency effects. Hereâ€™s a first look at the behavior when the currency method is activated.

For all revenue recognition methods, Event-Based Revenue Recognition (EBRR) uses a principal currency for period-end closing activities. The principal currency is the reference currency used during the re-evaluation of EBRR at period-end. Re-evaluation is performed either automatically during the period-end closing run or manually for a specific WBS billing element. Its purpose is to adjust revenue recognition based on updated data, net balance sheet accounts, andâ€”if necessaryâ€”recalculate the entire object, for example due to changes in plan.

For the new EBRR key, the object currency is used as the principal currency. In project-based scenarios, this corresponds to the project currency.

What differentiates the new approach from the Currency Method SPACE in the existing key SPFC is that, during period-end closing, both the company code currency and the global currency are translated.

As a result, no currency effects are calculated in the transaction currency. The value in transaction currency always corresponds to the current percentage of completion (POC) multiplied by the planned revenue in the object currency. Currency effects are recognized in both the company code currency and the global currency.

It is also important to understand that the EBRR period-end calculation does not re-evaluate the posted WIP or realized revenue using the current exchange rate; this revaluation can instead be performed using AFCV.

In our example, we have seen two situations; WIP exceeding deferred revenue and TECO set with remaining WIP. These are just two of several possible cases. 

There are additional rules the currency method follows, depending on the situation.

Letâ€™s look at how the system behaves in other posting scenarios. 

To better understand this, letâ€™s briefly recap the general logic of period-end closing â€” independent of the currency method. Period-end closing reads all actual costs and revenues posted to the billing or cost WBS element, along with the relevant plan data. Based on this, the system calculates the current POC, which is then used to determine the updated WIP and realized revenue.

POC change caused by new EAC calculation

Even if there are no actual postings added, a new POC may be calculated based on adjusted plan/ EAC data, which leads to a revised recognized revenue.

One reason could be a currency effect in EAC calculation. This can especially happen, if you use plan source 305 or 306. In the CPM application, resource/ cost planning is always done in project/object currency. For source 305 and 306, the planned costs need to be converted into Company Code currency to calculate POC. This conversion also uses the 'M' exchange rate from the first day of the posting period.

Using plan source 303, there could be a new updated baseline. For source 500 you could use new updated plan data.

The system reacts the following:

  • If there is additional revenue recognized, it is translated into company code and global currency with
    •  the rate of the period if no open WIP at period end exists.
    • If WIP exists, the revenue is translated with the historic (average) WIP rate
    • If there is a revenue deduction calculated it is translated with the FIFO rate

If the result is that accrued revenue exceeds deferred revenue, a few things need to be considered â€” in addition to the posting behavior already shown in the system example.

  • A new POC is calculated based on current actuals and plan data, which can lead to a revised recognized revenue:

The period end process nets accrued and deferred revenue, adjusts recognized revenue accordingly, and calculates currency effects. Recognized revenue is posted using the historic (average) rate of the WIP.

  • If a TECO status is set and POC is changed, a revaluation is triggered using the average exchange rate of the open WIP at that time.

Background: According to IAS 21, revenue must be recognized using the spot exchange rate at the time the service is performed. When a project is set to TECO and revenue has been earned across multiple periods, a single exchange rate is not sufficient. Instead, an average rate based on the remaining open WIP is calculated to reflect the blended spot rates over time. 

Another possible outcome is that deferred revenue exceeds accrued revenue.

Letâ€™s walk through a simple example to illustrate how currency effects can arise during period-end closing.

Step 1: Initial cost posting in June

In June, there is a time confirmation of 10 hours, posted at an exchange rate of 1:1,1 (GBP to EUR). This results in:

  • Â£1,200 in the transaction currency (GBP)
  • â‚¬1.320 in the company code currency (EUR)

Figure 15: Initial cost posting June

 

 

 

Step 2. Billing 

Two invoices are posted in June:

  • On June 17, an invoice for Â£1,000 / â‚¬1.200 at an exchange rate of 1.2
  • On June 18, an invoice for Â£1,500 / â‚¬1.950 at an exchange rate of 1.3

Figure 16 : Step 2 : Billing

With this, a weighted average exchange rate is derived for the deferred revenue:

  • â‚¬3.150 / Â£2,500 = 1,26

Step 3: EBRR Period end

At period-end, the deferrals are netted using this weighted average rate.

Figure 17 : EBRR Period end June

  • The system clears Â£1,200 from deferred revenue.
  • Using the weighted rate of 1,26, this corresponds to â‚¬1.512 (1.200 * 1.26).

 Step 4: Calculating Currency Effects

However, only â‚¬1,320 was recognized as WIP earlier (based on the original rate of 1,1).

This results in a currency effect of â‚¬192:

  • â‚¬1,512 (clearing) â€“ â‚¬1.320 (WIP) = â‚¬192 currency difference

The status is set to Completed (TECO) when deferred revenue exceeds accrued revenue, which is another possible scenario.

This situation can also lead to currency effects during period-end processing.

  • The period end process identifies recognized revenue and open WIP that has not yet been invoiced
  • Compute an average WIP exchange rate based on the open WIP items. This rate represents a weighted average of the spot rates applicable at the time each portion of the WIP was earned.
  • Use the calculated average rate to convert the revenue from the transaction currency to the company code currency. This ensures revenue is recognized appropriately in line with the actual earning periods

 Background: According to IAS 21, revenue must be recognized using the spot       exchange rate at the time the service is performed. When a project is set to TECO   and revenue has been earned across multiple periods, a single exchange rate is  not sufficient. Instead, an average rate based on the remaining open WIP is calculated to reflect the blended spot rates over time. 

  • The remaining open WIP can be fully cleared

Down payment

Fixed price projects continue to be supported by the down payment process. The new currency method has no impact on down payment handling. The established posting logic remains unchanged. This includes the netting of the down payment contract liability with a possible WIP balance. 

What is new in this context is that the netting now receives its own SLALI-Type.: 08103 Accrued Revenue Adjustment by Down Payment Liability Clearing. This change allows the currency method to identify and exclude netting lines from currency conversion logic.

 

4.    Control in event-based revenue recognition 

To enable the functionality described above, the key SPFCFX has been delivered.

This key uses the new revenue recognition method 25, which uses cost-based POC based on company code currency and uses the new currency logic. It is hardcoded linked to currency method 28. Using the currency method, currency effects are calculated and WIP is reduced based on FIFO.

Figure 18 : EBRR Key SPFCFX

For this new key, it is now possible to choose between four different plan sources â€“ a functionality that is also new and delivered with release 2508.

There is now an SSC UI available in EBRR configuration that allows you to assign the supported plan sources to the new key.

As part of the new currency method rollout, manual plan data is now supported, source 500, â€” as shown in the system example.

In addition, the new key is also supported by plan sources 303, 305, and 306.

Sources 305 and 306 are specifically used for CPM projects and are integrated via the Review Customer Projects App, which allows to manually adjust EAC and POC. This planning data is considered by EBRR, independent of the used cost-based POC method.

Before we get into the SSC UI, letâ€™s start with a brief overview of the plan data and what it means in the context of revenue recognition.

  • 303: Here we take the plan costs from ACDOCP, which are updated by CPM baseline (baseline plan category).  Plan costs exist in transaction, company, and global currency. Currency conversion takes place once during baseline creation or when the baseline is updated. With this POC effects from exchange rates changes are avoided. The planned revenue is based on CPM/SD billing plan. These planned data are used in real-time and period-end processing.
  • 305 (Default): Plan costs from CPM resource planning converted to company code currency with 'M' of the current periodâ€“Plan revenues from CPM/SD billing plan. If there are manual adjustments made in the Review Customer Project, the review app plan data are considered.
  • 306: Real-time: Same as 305 â€“ plan costs from CPM, plan revenues from CPM/SD billing plan. The period end run uses the actual estimation (EAC) from the Review Customer Project App, while planned revenue is derived from the CPM/SD billing plan. This may lead to POC adjustments.
  • 500: Plan costs and revenues from ACDOCP, based on manual plan category.
    Used in real-time and period-end.

The existing SSCUI now allows assignment of a plan source.

Figure 19: Source of plan values - overview

The following sources can be selected via the F4 help:

Figure 20 : Plan sources details

For the first time, this release introduces the possibility to work with manual plan data in CPM projects. If you want to use the manual version, you first need to set it up in the 'Maintain Category for Planning' app.

Figure 21 : manual plan category for projects

With the assignment of application type â€œProject Managementâ€ additional checks and derivation logic are provided by the plan update.

A WBS element must be provided for every planning line item. This prevents an accidental deletion of planned data provided for other projects, which can happen when you use a periodic plan category like PLN.

The account assignment type â€œWBS elementâ€œ is determined for all planning line items and additional attributes are taken from the project and assigned sales order item like profit center or margin analysis fields are derived and stored for the planning line items.

The 'Import Financial Plan Data' app is required to upload plan data. The app provides an option to download a template for project planning.

Figure 22 : Import manual plan data

After uploading, the data can be viewed.

Figure 23: Display uploaded manual plan data

5.    EBRR key change for a WBS billing element

The change of the EBRR key from the previously used key SPFC to the new one is supported and enables future postings to follow the updated currency method.

There are, however, a few general aspects to consider when making this change.

  • Recognized Revenues already posted will not be recalculated retrospectively .
  • New calculated recognized revenue with key SPFCX will be translated with the currency rate of the current period â€“ even if the confirmation was posted in previous periods.
  • Different options are available for executing the change (see next figure 24).
  • The remaining duration of the project should be considered when deciding on the appropriate approach.
  • For transparency reasons if you directly change to new key it is recommended to keep the plan source the same. If you change indirectly with intermediate steps in between as shown in figure 25, you could change the plan source
  • Restriction: At the time of transition, no open Contract Liabilities for down payments must exist. If open Contract Liabilities are present, the currency effect calculation will not work correctly.

First, an overview of the key differences between the keys:

Figure 24 : Differences SPFC - SPFCFX

Switching from an existing revenue recognition key to the new EBRR key could be performed with two options, both following a two-step process within the same posting period.

Option 1: Temporary Switch via 'non Rev Rec' Key

  1. Replace the current revenue recognition key with a 'non Rev Rec' key.
  2. Run the first period-end closing using the 'non Rev Rec' key to clear existing balances without triggering revenue recognition.
  3. Update the key to the new EBRR key.
  4. Run the period-end closing again for the same period using the new key.

Option 2: TECO and Reopen Approach

  1. Set the project to Completed (TECO) status.
  2. Run the period-end closing with the existing revenue recognition key to finalize the old logic.
  3. Reopen the project by resetting the status.
  4. Assign the new EBRR key.
  5. Execute a second period-end closing for the same period using the new key.

Figure 25 : EBRR Key change

 1 With SPFC, the global currency is not handled by EBRR at all â€“ it is always calculated by RWIN. Any balance in global currency is only processed at TECO.

After switching to SPFCX, however, the global currency (as well as all other currencies) is now handled by EBRR.

Remark: the direct change to SPFCX is not recommended as there will be EBRR data, which does not align with new method â€“ e.g. transaction currency not in project currency. New features like currency effects, are not fully supported in a direct switch from SPFC to SPFCFX, remaining potential WIP from SPFC process is reduced as posted, using the frozen rate. . Global currency of already posted EBRR journal entries are translated by RWIN and not EBRR.

 Closing remarks

We hope you enjoyed this new EBBR functionality for customer projects in S/4HANA public cloud. It is another scenario, in which we are now benefiting from the innovations in financial accounting.

Feedback welcome

entry.title: How I Fixed â€œnon-fast-forwardâ€ and â€œunrelated historiesâ€ Git Errors â€“ Real-World Debugging
entry.content:
Overview of My Issue:

While working on a Bitbucket hosted SAP UI5 project, I tried to push my local changes to the remote development branch as my first commit using: git push origin development

 

Screenshot 1.1: Non-Fast-Forward Error

Because, my current branch is behind the remote and git is preventing me from accidentally overwriting changes.

To fix this, I attempted to pull the latest changes from the remote branch: git pull origin development

Again i received the fatal: refusing to merge unrelated histories error as below:

Screenshot 1.2: Refusing to merge unrelated histories

This is because my local and remote repositories had no shared commit history.

 

Steps I followed to resolve the issue

Here's how I resolved the issue in a few steps:

Step 1: Allow Merging Unrelated Histories

git pull origin development --allow-unrelated-histories

This command tells git to merge two separate project histories, even if theyâ€™re not connected. It's usually needed when:

â€¢ You created a local repository using  git init before linking it to a remote one

â€¢ The remote repository already has some commits, like a README or .gitignore file

Screenshot 1.3: Running the --allow-unrelated-histories command

 

Step 2: Resolve Merge Conflicts (If Any)

Git may pause and ask us to resolve merge conflicts. Open the files, resolve the changes, and then run following commands:

git add .

git commit -m "Merged unrelated histories"

Screenshot 1.4: Merge unrelated histories

 

Step 3: Push Successfully

Once everything was committed, I finally ran:

git push origin development

And it worked! My changes were safely pushed to the remote branch.

Here you can see the actual bitbucket commit section for better understanding

 

Why This Happens

This is common when:

  • When we created a local repo without cloning the remote first
  • The remote repo already had commits we donâ€™t have locally
  • Histories diverge and git can't auto-resolve them

Instead of force-pushing and risking overwrite, Git stops us and let's merge safely.

 

Take away points:

  • Never force push (--force) unless we are sure that we are not overwriting someone elseâ€™s work.
  • Use git log --oneline --graph to understand commit history visually.
  • Always pull before push. Keeps your repo safe from conflicts.

Git errors can be confusing at first glance, but once we understand the intent behind them, they actually protect our code.

If you're working with SAP UI5, Fiori or any frontend Git workflow. This is a handy fix to remember.

Thank you for taking the time to read this blog! Please suggest your way of approach!

If you found this helpful, feel free to share your thoughts, feedback or questions in the comments! Let's keep learning and growing together. Happy coding!

entry.title: Advanced ATP Product Allocation (PAL) integration: SAP IBP to S/4HANA
entry.content:
Advanced ATP Product Allocation (PAL) integration: SAP IBP to S/4HANA

In Advanced ATP (aATP), one of the key functionalities is Product Allocation (PAL), which ensures the fair distribution of a limited supply based on specific business-defined parameters, such as customer or region.

In an integrated SAP IBPâ€“S/4HANA setup, allocation planning occurs in IBP, while allocation consumption and checks take place on the S/4 side. Thatâ€™s the reason transferring PAL data from IBP to S4HANA is important.

 During my project requirement, I was involved in building this interface in the client system, and based on the same experience, I captured the functional side of developing the interface between IBP and S4. Also, I documented the issues I faced in the 'Factors to be considered' section of the blog. 

Business Scenario:

Letâ€™s take an example from the automotive industry, managing constrained components like EV batteries has become a critical supply chain priority. Original Equipment Manufacturers (OEMs) must ensure that these limited parts are allocated to dealershipsâ€”often across global regionsâ€”without disturbing customer commitments.

SAP IBP is typically used to plan product allocations at a granular level (e.g., Product + Plant + Customer Group) based on forecasted demand and capacity constraints. However, the actual order fulfilment and availability checks occur in SAP S/4HANA using Advanced ATP (AATP)- Product Availability Check (PAC) functionality.

To ensure real-time synchronization between planning and execution, it becomes essential to transfer PAL data from IBP to S/4HANA, where AATP can enforce allocation limits during sales order creation.

I have created a PAL object in S/4HANA based on the following characteristics, like Customer Group, Plant, and Material Number.

An automotive OEM manufactures electric vehicles across three global plants. Due to a global shortage of lithium-ion battery packs:

  • Allocation planning is done in IBP, assigning weekly quantities of battery packs to each plant and customer group (e.g., retail, Government accounts, etc.).
  • These allocation limits are exported from IBP and pushed to S/4HANA using the SAP standard API API_PRODUCT_ALLOCATION_OBJECT_SRV.
  • When dealers place new vehicle orders, AATP PAC checks the current PAL object to determine whether the battery supply is still available for that period and the customer group and Plant combination.
  • If allocation is exhausted, the order is rescheduled, split, or denied based on AATP logic.

     

Solution approach: Mostly, the solution design covers the following points

  • Pre-requisites:
  1. PAL functionality should be activated in the system. (Please refer to the SAP Help portal for more information: Reference section)
  2. The PAL object should be configured in the system, and the FIORI configuration should be completed.
  3. Finite Heuristic Solve should be completed in SAP IBP, and a Constrained Supply Plan should be generated.

     Step-by-step Solution approach: 

            1. PAL Data Extraction from IBP

  •  Time-series-based PAL data is maintained in SAP IBP using planning operators or manual input.
  •  Data can be extracted via OData API (e.g., using SAP CPI).
  • The extract contains fields like Product, Location, Date, Allocation Quantity, and CVC attributes (e.g., Customer Group).

             2. Transformation Layer (SAP CPI)

  • Transform IBP field names and structures to match the input structure of API_PRODUCT_ALLOCATION_OBJECT_SRV.
  • Based on the business requirement, convert the time bucket values, like weekly/monthly buckets from IBP are converted to daily values, as required by S/4.

             3. API-Based Upload to S/4HANA

        Use the OData service API_PRODUCT_ALLOCATION_OBJECT_SRV. 

  1. Create or update Product Allocation Object headers (A_ProductAllocationObject)
  2. Create associated items (A_ProductAllocationObjectItem) for characteristics.
  3. Upload time-series allocations (A_ProductAllocationTimeSeries)

          4. Validation & Error Handling

            Errors such as:  Invalid Master Data (e.g., Product) in S4 and Missing Characteristics. 

 

Factors to be considered:

Based on my recent Project experience during the development of this interface, I faced a couple of issues, which I tried to capture as follows:

As this solution requires proper alignment between SAP IBP and OTC, smooth and timely coordination is the key factor between the two teams to achieve the desired results

                1.   Alignment of Planning and Consumption Time Buckets

  • IBP typically uses weekly time buckets.
  • S/4HANA AATP may expect monthly PAL buckets (time series per month).
  •  Use CPI or ABAP logic to merge weekly allocations into monthly values, as required.

               2. Characteristic Value Combinations (CVCs)

  • IBP can plan at aggregated levels like Product/Location/Customer Group.
  • PAL in S/4 needs exact matching characteristics, e.g., Product + Plant + Customer Group.
  • All characteristics in S/4 must be available as fields in the PAL object.
  • Mismatch in CVCs causes API rejection. 
  • During the selection of CVCs, we should consider the volume of data load in S/4 to avoid any performance issues. 

               3. API Volume and Performance

  • Use batch calls in the OData API for bulk data uploads. SAP Note 3042321 offers performance tips. (Check the Reference section: G)

               4. Misc. Considerations

  • Overwriting Existing Allocations? Define logic for overwrite vs. append. Consider this a critical one. 
  • Emergency Allocation Changes? How will last-minute changes be pushed (manual vs. automated)? Business has to align with the same. 
  • PAL and Backorder Processing (BOP): Ensure PAL object updates align with scheduled BOP runs.
  • How to handle obsolete PAL objects in S/4 (Archival vs. Deletion)? Check with the business team on how to handle this post-go-live scenario when the system will have a large number of PAL objects down the line. 
  • Check with the business regarding the volume of transactions beforehand to avoid any last-minute surprises.

               5. Notification System

  • Send email/SAP alert for: Repeated failures, Bulk upload errors, etc. 

Conclusion:

Integrating SAP IBP with S/4HANA for Product Allocation (PAL) is a critical step toward enabling intelligent, constraint-based order promising through AATP. By leveraging the SAP standard OData API, an organization can automate and streamline the transfer of allocation quantities and characteristic combinations. The end success depends on the testing part with the business team in the non-production environment. 

Please share your questions, comments, and feedback.

References:

  1. IBP Interaction with aATP â€“ Transfer of Product Allocation Data
  2. General & performance recommendations for "Manage Product Allocation Planning Data" - App with a huge no. of CVCs / API_PRODUCT_ALLOCATION_OBJECT_SRV
  3. https://api.sap.com/api/API_PRODUCT_ALLOCATION_OBJECT_SRV/overview
  4. Product Allocation (CA-ATP-PAL) | SAP Help Portal

Introduction

Sometimes it's necessary to debug code to find a bug â€” it happened to me too. Back then, our only solution was to use tools like â€œgroovyIDEâ€, where we could print output to the console, just like old-school PHP developers.

A few months ago, I published a Visual Studio Code extension that provides similar functionality to â€œgroovyIDEâ€ but for a local environment. This local setup also supports external libraries, such as JWT libraries.

The new version of the VS Code extension now allows debugging Groovy scripts locally using JDI (Java Debug Interface). I developed a tool that enables this functionality. Currently, it does not support all Java or Groovy classes.

What do you need?

  • Visual studio Code 
  • SAP CPI Groovy Script
  • Java 1.8
  • Groovy 2.4
  • SAP CPI Extension tools 

Installing and Configuring the Extension in VS Code

entry.title: Simple RAP based Managed UI development with Create & Delete actions on custom BillDoc header table
entry.content:
Introduction

In this project, you set out to build a Simple Managed RAP (ABAP RESTful Application Programming) application on SAP BTP ABAP Environment using Eclipse ADT. The goal is to design a lightweight Billing Document Header maintenance app with Create and Delete capabilities, following best practices for Managed RAP development.

The application uses a custom transparent table for storing billing document header data and implements standard RAP layers â€” Database Table, Interface View, Projection View, Metadata Annotations, Behavior Definitions, Service Definition, and Service Binding.

By leveraging Managed RAP,  you do not need to write custom CRUD logic â€” the framework auto-generates this functionality, allowing you to focus purely on data modelling, UI annotations, and service exposure. This demonstrates how RAP accelerates application development in the cloud while complying with ABAP Cloud clean-core principles.

 

Objectives:

Creating a Simple Managed RAP based UI using BTP and Eclipse IDE with Create & Delete actions on custom Billing Document header table.

Requirements/Task(s):

  1. Create required Database Table(s)
  2. Create CDS views for the Database Table â€“
    • Interface View and
    • Consumption (Projection) View
  3. Create Metadata View on Consumption View
  4. Create Behavior Definition for Interface View
  5. Create Behavior Definition for Consumption View
  6. Create Service Definition for Consumption View
  7. Service Binding for the Service Definition
  8. Test the Application

Objects List

 

Outline the steps/plan for your project:

  1. Step1: Create Database Table (Eclipse - Data Dictionary-Database Table)

 

 

Check the created Database Table structure (Right click â€“ Open With - Data Preview)

 

Step 2: Create Interface Root view CDS for the database table created (right click database table - Data Definitions - Root View template)

           

 

Step 3: Create Consumption/Projection Root view CDS for the database table created (right click database table - Data Definitions - Root View template)

           

Step 4: Create Metadata that helps with designing aspects of the UI (Right click on the Projection View you created and select new "Metadata Definition")

           

Step 5: Create Behaviour Definition - one fore Interface view and one for Consumption view you have created

Step 5a: Create Behaviour Definition for the interface view ((Right click the Interface CDS View and choose Behaviour Definition option)

                       

Step 5b: Create Behaviour Definition for the Projection view (Right click the Projection CDS View and choose Behaviour Definition option)

Step 6: Create Service definition (Right click CDS Projection View and click "New Service Definition")

Expose the Consumption View CDS.

                       

 

Step 7: Create Service Binding (Right click on the new Service definition you created and choose "New Service Binding" and Choose OData V4 version for the UI)

Select the Service Definition displayed on the versions section of the page and hit "Publish" button.

It will take some time. Once it is done, a Service URL will be created and the binding will be displayed.

  

 

Step 8:  Test the Application: Select the Entity and hit Preview button, a new Window will be opened with the RAP UI App you created.

                    

 

 

A new window will open with the UI for the Application we created:

 

 

Click â€œGoâ€ Button, so that the values are pulled from the Database table to be shown on the screen.

 

 

You can see the database records displayed on the screen. The Create and Delete buttons are available for creating new records and deleting existing records. Since this is Managed RAP application, the code necessary for the Create and delete operations are handled automatically by the Framework, there is no explicit code necessary for these simple actions. If customizations are required then it can be handled via Implementation Class (Behaviour Pool Classes) of the Behaviour Definition.

Project link:

https://github.com/ABAPAnitha/RAP-for-Bill-doc-header-and-Items

Conclusion

This project highlights how quickly and efficiently a Managed RAP application can be built on SAP BTP using the ABAP RESTful Programming Model. The framework automatically handled the Create and Delete operations, proving the advantage of Managed scenarios where minimal custom coding is required.

We also learned how UI metadata annotations can be used to control the look and feel of the Fiori Elements-based UI without any frontend coding, and how RAPâ€™s structured approach â€” from database table to service binding â€” enables a clean, maintainable, and extensible application design.

Going forward, you can extend this solution with:

  • Custom business logic in Behavior Pool classes,

  • Associations to billing item entities for a complete billing document structure,

  • Advanced annotations for richer UI interactions.

Overall, the Managed RAP approach proved to be a fast, cloud-compliant, and developer-friendly way to deliver maintainable SAP applications aligned with the ABAP Cloud strategy.

entry.title: SAP Job Scheduling Service: Set Job Run Status with the REST API, CF CLI, bash and curl
entry.content:
ðŸš€ Introduction

 

Sometimes things go wrong. Youâ€™ve scheduled an asynchronous (long-running) background job using the SAP Job Scheduling Service on BTP, and your app endpoint was triggered. But something failed â€” maybe the app timed out, crashed, or didnâ€™t properly call back to update the job status.

As a result, the job run is stuck in an ACK_RECEIVED state and will eventually go to UNKNOWN. This can cause confusion in your monitoring tools or delay in alert resolution.

This post shows how to manually override the status of a stuck job run by calling the SAP Job Scheduling Update Job Run Log REST API using bash, curl and jq. (if you prefer NodeJs and UIs check Set Job Run Status with the REST API and Node.js)

For more cool Job Scheduling Service Blog Posts check the Overview page

ðŸ§  Why Manual Overrides Are Needed

The SAP Job Scheduler supports both synchronous and asynchronous jobs. When the scheduler triggers an asynchronous job (like an HTTP endpoint), it expects your application to call back once it's completed and update the job run status using the API.

If this call doesnâ€™t happen â€” for example, the app ðŸ’€ dies before responding â€” the scheduler doesnâ€™t assume success or failure. The job remains in an intermediate state (ACK_RECEIVED) and might eventually be marked as UNKNOWN.

To fix this, we can manually call the schedulerâ€™s REST API and set the run to FAILURE or SUCCESS.

ðŸ”§ Update Job Run Log API Overview

Endpoint:

PUT /scheduler/jobs/{jobId}/schedules/{scheduleId}/runs/{runId}

Sample request body:

{
  "success": false,
  "message": "Manually failed due to timeout or missing callback"
}

This call requires:

  • The Job ID, Schedule ID, and Run ID (must be known beforehand)
  • A valid OAuth token from your Job Scheduler service instance

When successful, the runâ€™s status will be updated to FAILURE, and monitoring tools will reflect this immediately.

Creating service-keys

We need a service keys for the instances so that we can "talk" to the REST API. We can create these service keys either in the cockpit or using the CLI (example below).

cf login
 
cf create-service-key denis-scheduler service-key
 
cf service-key denis-scheduler service-key | sed -n '/^{/,/^}/p' > service-key.txt
 

We've name it service-key.txt and downloaded it in the same directory as the script.

The Bash Script

There are 4 simple steps in the script:

  1. ðŸ” Load the Service Key
  2. ðŸ”‘ Authenticate via OAuth2
  3. ðŸ› ï¸ Call the Update Job Run Log API
  4. ðŸš€ Run the Script

update-job-status.sh

#!/usr/bin/env bash

set -euo pipefail

# Ensure required environment variables are set
if [[ -z "${JOB_ID:-}" || -z "${SCHEDULE_ID:-}" || -z "${RUN_ID:-}" ]]; then
  echo "âŒ Error: JOB_ID, SCHEDULE_ID, and RUN_ID environment variables must be set." >&2
  echo "Usage: JOB_ID=<job_id> SCHEDULE_ID=<schedule_id> RUN_ID=<run_id> ./update-job-status.sh" >&2
  exit 1
fi

# ðŸ” ========================= LOAD SERVICE KEY ========================= ðŸ”
SERVICE_KEY_FILE="service-key.txt"
SERVICE_KEY_CONTENT=$(cat "$SERVICE_KEY_FILE")

UAA_URL=$(echo "$SERVICE_KEY_CONTENT" | jq -r '.uaa.url')
CLIENT_ID=$(echo "$SERVICE_KEY_CONTENT" | jq -r '.uaa.clientid')
CLIENT_SECRET=$(echo "$SERVICE_KEY_CONTENT" | jq -r '.uaa.clientsecret')
SERVICE_URL=$(echo "$SERVICE_KEY_CONTENT" | jq -r '.url')

# ðŸ”‘ ========================= AUTHENTICATION ============================ ðŸ”‘
ACCESS_TOKEN=$(curl -s \
  -u "$CLIENT_ID:$CLIENT_SECRET" \
  -d "grant_type=client_credentials" \
  "$UAA_URL/oauth/token" | jq -r '.access_token')

# ðŸ› ï¸ ========================= UPDATE JOB RUN STATUS ========================= ðŸ› ï¸
curl -s -X PUT "$SERVICE_URL/scheduler/jobs/$JOB_ID/schedules/$SCHEDULE_ID/runs/$RUN_ID" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $ACCESS_TOKEN" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"success": false, "message": "Manually failed due to stuck ACK_RECEIVED status"}'

echo "âœ… Job run status manually set to FAILED"
 

Make the script executable:

chmod +x update-job-status.sh
 

Run it:

JOB_ID="<YOUR_JOB_ID>" SCHEDULE_ID="<YOUR_SCHEDULE_ID>" RUN_ID="<YOUR_RUN_ID>" ./update-job-status.sh

Result:

ðŸ” Optional: Verifying the Update

You can extend the Bash Script above to validate the state of the execution:

# ðŸ” ========================= VERIFY JOB RUN STATUS ========================= ðŸ”
echo "ðŸ” Verifying job run status..."

RUN_DETAILS=$(curl -s -X GET "$SERVICE_URL/scheduler/jobs/$JOB_ID/schedules/$SCHEDULE_ID/runs/$RUN_ID" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $ACCESS_TOKEN" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json")

echo "$RUN_DETAILS" | jq .

âš ï¸ Best Practices

  • Only override runs if youâ€™re certain the original job has failed or stalled.
  • Include a clear reason in the message field (useful for audits and logs).
  • Log each override operation in your own system.

ðŸ“„ Summary

entry.title: Create CDS Views and expose through OData service in CAPM
entry.content:
Hi, in this blog Iâ€™m going to explain how to create CDS Views and expose through OData service in CAPM.

Here we have discussion about to create CDS views and expose through OData service on SAP Business Application Studio with Cloud Application Programming Model (CAPM).

 

Step-1: We have to create a CAPM application with Business Application Studio. Create a new folder in workspace with name "zviewcreation".

Step-2: Open terminal and enter "cds init" to initialize the cap application. You can see db, srv and app folders are created.

Step-3: Now create new file in db folder as "data-model.cds" and add entities "products" and "orderitems" as below.

namespace zviewcreation.db;

entity products {
    key ID            : UUID;
        PRODUCT_ID    : String(30);
        PRODUCT_NAME  : String(250);
        CATEGORY      : String(32);
        CURRENCY_CODE : String(4);
        PRICE         : Decimal(15, 2);
        orderitem     : Association to one orderitems;
}

entity orderitems {
    key NODE_KEY   : UUID;
        ORDER_ID   : String(30);
        ORDER_DATE : Date;
        products   : Association to many products
                         on products.orderitem = $self;
}

Step-4: Now create new file in db folder as "cdsview.cds" and add views "Product" and "productsOrders" as below.

namespace zviewcreation.dbview;

using {zviewcreation.db} from './data-model';

define view ![Product] as
    select from db.products {
        PRODUCT_ID         as ![ProductId],
        PRODUCT_NAME       as ![ProductName],
        PRICE              as ![Price],
        CURRENCY_CODE      as ![Currency],
        orderitem.NODE_KEY as ![OrderKey]

    }

define view ![ProductsOrders] as
    select from db.orderitems
    mixin {
        PRODUCTS : Association[ * ] to Product
                       on PRODUCTS.OrderKey = $projection.OrderKey
    }
    into {
        NODE_KEY   as ![OrderKey],
        ORDER_ID   as ![OrderId],
        ORDER_DATE as ![OrderDate],
        PRODUCTS   as ![Products]

    }

Step-5: Create new file in srv folder with name "catservice.cds" and expose our cds view as entity set.

using { zviewcreation.dbview } from '../db/cdsview';

service MyService @(path: 'ProductsSrv') {

    entity ProductsOrdersSet as projection on dbview.ProductsOrders;

}

Step-6: Install node modules using "npm install" in terminal.

Step-7: Now run the application using "cds watch" .

Step-8: You will be able to see our OData service.

Step-9: You can add data to our entities by doing "cds add data" in terminal. As a result 2 files will be added in data folder in db folder in the format of "<your namespace>-<entity name>.csv".

Step-10: Add some sample data to both files as below.

Step-11: Now again do "cds watch" and select "ProductsOrdersSet" to see the data.

Step-12: Now you can able to see ProductsOrdersSet data.

Step-13: Add "?$expand=Products" at end of the url and you will able to see all the data of orders with respective products.

 

 

Thatâ€™s it!!!

entry.title: Custom Journal Entry Query by G/L and Cost Center in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, reporting on Journal Entries often requires not only grouping by GL Accounts but also breaking down the information based on Cost Centers. This can be critical for department-level spend control or management reporting where even costs on the same account need to be analyzed separately.

In this blog post, I will show how to create a Custom Analytical Query that splits entries on the same GL account into separate rows based on Cost Center.

Use case

We want to analyze expenses posted to G/L account 61400000 ("Training and Education") across multiple cost centers. Although the same account is used, it is important to distinguish which department owns the expense.

 
Journal EntryG/L AccountAmountCost CenterCost Center Description
10000012361400000500HR001HR Department
10000012461400000300IT002IT Department
10000012561400000700SALES003Sales Department

Prerequisites

Ensure your user has the following roles assigned:

Business RoleBusiness Role ID
Analytics SpecialistSAP_BR_EXTENSIBILITY_SPEC
General Ledger AccountantSAP_BR_GL_ACCOUNTANT
 
If you donâ€™t have the necessary roles, please contact your administrator or refer to the Maintain Business Users app.

Implementation

To implement the custom query, youâ€™ll create a new Custom Analytical Query in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition based on the standard data source I_JournalEntryItemCube.

Within the query, youâ€™ll define Restricted Structure Elements to represent specific combinations of G/L Accounts and Cost Centers. This allows you to display postings to the same account in separate rows depending on the cost center dimension. If required, you can further build a Ð¡ustom Report or Fiori tile on top of the query for easier access and integration into business users' daily activities.

1. Open the Custom Analytical Queries app (F1572)

Click "Create"

2. Create a Custom Analytical Query

In the opened window, set the Query Name (for example, CUSTOMREPORT), Data Source (I_JOURNALENTRYITEMCUBE) and select "OK".

To implement the custom report, youâ€™ll create a new Custom Analytical Query in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition based on the standard data source I_JournalEntryItemCube.

3. Fill in the parameters in the "General" tab

The General window is used to configure the main properties of a custom analytical query. It provides key settings that define the query's behavior, metadata, and runtime characteristics.

  • Label â€“ name for the query that will be displayed in the system (e.g. CUSTOMREPORT)
  • Processing Effort â€“ allows prioritization of query performance (e.g. High)
  • Runtime Extensibility â€“ a checkbox indicating whether runtime extensibility is enabled for the query.
  • Handling  â€“ specifies how zero values in the query results are handled (e.g. None)
  • Hide on Axis â€“ determines whether zero-suppressed rows or columns are hidden (e.g. Rows & Columns)

After filling in the fields, navigate to the Field Selection tab.

4. Define the fields in the "Field Selection" tab

The "Field Selection" window is used to define the fields included in the query and specify how they are positioned in the query output (e.g., as rows, columns, or free fields). This setup controls the structure and content of the query results.

Available Fields â€“ displays a list of all fields available from the query's data source.

  • Selected Fields â€“ shows the fields that have been added to the query.
  • Row â€“ fields added to this section will define the row structure of the query results.
  • Column â€“ fields added to this section define the column structure of the query results.
  • Free â€“ fields in this section are not directly displayed in the query results but are available for filtering or grouping during query execution.

Selected Fields â€“ displays the fields that have been added to the query. It includes fields selected from the Available Fields section and organizes them into Row, Column, Measure Structure, or Free, depending on their role in the report layout.

After selecting the fields, navigate to the Display tab.

5. Define the fields in the "Display" tab

The "Display" window is used to configure the layout and behavior of fields in the query output. It allows users to determine which fields appear as rows, columns, or free fields, as well as customize properties such as display options, sorting, and formatting. Fields can be reassigned between Row, Column, and Free using either drag-and-drop or the Axis property in the Properties panel or Up, Down, Add buttons.

To enhance your report logic, additional elements can be added via the Add button:

  • Add Restricted Measure â€“ creates a key figure with a predefined filter condition (e.g., only for a specific company code or fiscal year).
  • Add Calculated Measure â€“ defines new key figures based on arithmetic or logical operations involving existing ones.
  • Add Converted Measure â€“ generates a key figure with unit conversion applied (e.g., currency or quantity unit).
  • Add Counter â€“ introduces a counter that increments for each record, which is useful for record numbering or counting occurrences.
  • Add User Input Filter â€“ adds a filter field that prompts the user to enter a value during query execution. This allows for dynamic filtering based on user input.
  • Add Characteristic Structure Element â€“ enables more advanced layout or logic customization by defining reusable field structures.

In our example, we will use a Characteristic Structure Element to customize the output view of the query. To add it, Ñlick the Add button and select Add Characteristic Structure Element from the dropdown menu.

In the dialog window that opens, select "OK".

In the Characteristic Structure Element dialog, you can define the properties of the structure element that will be added to your report layout:

  • Label â€“ specifies the display name of the structure element, which will appear as a column header in the query result (e.g., 1.1. HR Expenses).
  • Name â€“ provides a unique technical identifier for the structure element used internally within the query (e.g., HRExpenses).
  • Structure Element â€“ determines the type of structure element to create:
    • Restricted Structure Element â€“ aggregates data based on predefined filter criteria (e.g., specific G/L account and cost center).
    • Calculated Structure Element â€“ creates a key figure based on calculations involving other structure elements (e.g., differences, percentages).

In our example, we select Restricted Structure Element to isolate and display values that match specific filtering conditions.

Once the settings are defined, click OK to proceed.

6. Define Characteristic Structure Elements

Once the Characteristic Structure Element has been added, it appears in the Row section of the Display tab. On the right-hand side of the screen, the Properties allows further customization:

  • Label â€“ choose between a static label (manually defined) or a dynamic label (generated based on logic or field values). In our example, the element is Static.
  • Name â€“ the technical identifier for internal use in query logic.
  • Display â€“ enables or disables visibility of the element in the report output.
  • Decimals â€“ defines the number of decimal places shown in the report output.
  • Scaling â€“ allows automatic scaling of numerical values (e.g., thousands, millions).
  • Reverse Sign â€“ reverses the sign of key figure values, often used to display credits as negatives.

Hierarchy â€“ controls how the element behaves in a hierarchical display:

  • Collapsed â€“ when enabled, the hierarchy node is shown collapsed by default, hiding its children until expanded by the user.
  • Enable Hierarchy â€“ activates the hierarchy mode for the element, allowing parent-child relationships to be displayed. 
  • Parent â€“ specifies the parent node for the current element when hierarchy mode is active.

Collision Handling â€“ defines how formatting and calculation settings are applied when different definitions conflict:

  • Formula â€“ determines whether the formula from the current element or from the collision source takes precedence.
  • Decimal â€“ specifies which decimal setting  should be applied in case of conflict.
  • Scaling â€“ specifies which scaling factor should be applied in case of conflict.

In the Fixed Values section at the bottom, you can define restrictions that determine which data is included in the structure element. In this case, a fixed filter is applied on the Account Assignment field using the Include option. This filter is the core of the Restricted Structure Element, as it ensures that only relevant records (e.g., for a specific G/L account and cost center) are used in calculations.

To refine the restriction criteria, click Add Restriction. You can specify multiple conditions based on various dimensions, such as G/L Account, Cost Center, or Functional Area.

In the Dimensions window, select the G/L Account field.


On the Include tab, select the "=" operator and define the account 61400000.

Similarly, define the restriction for cost center HR001.
To remove an unnecessary restriction (for example,  Account Assignment), select the Remove Restriction function.

Similarly, define the Characteristic Structure Element for 1.2. IT Expenses (account 61400000, cost center IT002) and 1.3. Sales Expenses (account 61400000, cost center SALES003).

To add a node, select Add Characteristic Structure Element and define the Label, Name, and Structure Element (Calculated Structure Element).
To define a summation formula for the previously created expense rows, go to the Expression section and click Edit.
Define the formula using mathematical operators and the list of available measures.
To define the created node as hierarchical, go to the previously created expense rows, check Enable Hierarchy in the Hierarchy section, and specify the parent node.

7. Define the fields in the "Filters" tab

The Filters tab is used to define the selection criteria that control which data is displayed in the report or structure. Filters help limit the dataset to the relevant scope by specifying fixed values, allowing user input during execution, or leaving the field unrestricted.

For the selected fields, you can define the following filter settings:

  • No filters â€“ allows all values; no restriction applied.
  • Fixed Values â€“ choosing fixed values defines a permanent filter value. End users cannot reconfigure this value. You can specify:
    • Include â€“ values that must be included in the dataset.
    • Exclude â€“ values that must be excluded from the dataset
  • User Input Values â€“ upon query execution, this option enables end users to choose a value that filters the result set. The following settings are possible for User Input Values:
    • Selection Type â€“ this option enables you to enter a single value, a value range, or a hierarchy node option to define the filter condition. The hierarchy node option appears only if a field supports a hierarchy. And the hierarchy node option displays the hierarchy tree in the User Input Filter screen.
    • Multiple Selection (checkbox) â€“ this option enables the end user to choose multiple values as input during query execution.
    • Mandatory (checkbox) â€“ this option ensures that the end user must make an entry.
    • Variable Sequence â€“ this option enables you to maintain the order of the parameter. During execution, the fields with variable sequence defined will take the first priority to the fields that have no value maintained for the same.
    • Default Value â€“ the value that you enter in this field appears in the User Input Value field and is displayed to the end user.
  • Derivation Functions â€“ this option enables automatically derive the filter value based on predefined logic or relationships with other fields. 
    • Lookup Entity â€“ defines the source for value help assistance for the field. This could be a CDS view, master data table, or other value provider.
    • Hide (checkbox) â€“ when selected, the field will not be displayed to the end user in the filter selection screen, but any fixed value or derivation logic applied to it will still be active during query execution.
    • Mandatory (checkbox) â€“ ensures that the filter must be provided before the query can be executed.

After defining all parameters (for example, Company Code, Ledger, Fiscal Year, Fiscal Period), you can save the draft of your Custom Analytical Query by selecting the Save Draft option. After saving, you can preview the custom query by selecting the Preview option.

In the window that opens, you will see a preview of your query.

After reviewing the query, you can return to the previous window and publish the Custom Analytical Query by clicking the Publish button.

After the query is successfully published, its status will change to Published.

Summary
In this blog post, we created a custom journal entry query by G/L account and cost center in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition.

We walked through the process of designing the query, configuring parameters and input options, previewing the results, and publishing it for use.

Once published, this query can serve as a powerful reporting tool, or act as a data source for custom applications, enabling more targeted financial insights.

Let me know if youâ€™ve implemented similar custom analytical queries!

entry.title: Bridging EDI and SAP S/4HANA Cloud: Seamless EDI-to-SOAP Integration
entry.content:
In the fast-paced world of business today, it's crucial to connect traditional EDI systems with modern cloud ERP systems for streamlined operations. This blog takes a closer look at an integration fllow that handles inbound EDI messages, transforms them into SOAP format and facilitate effortless communication with SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Let's explore how this approach changes data formats and guarantees a reliable,standards-complaint integration between legacy and cloud systems.

Note:  For detailed steps on creating and exporting the required MIG and MAG files used in this integration, please refer to the blog: Creating MIGs and MAGs Using Integration Advisor i... - SAP Community.

Step-by-Step Guide: EDI to SOAP Inbound Integration Flow

Hereâ€™s a detailed look at the entire integration flow (iFlow) for processing EDI to SOAP inbound messages. This iFlow covers all the essential steps and components needed to receive, validate, transform, and route EDI messages into SOAP format, ensuring a smooth connection to the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.

Step 1: Receive EDI Data via AS2

To initiate the integration, configure the AS2 adapter to receive inbound EDI messages. This configuration supports secure and reliable data transfer in B2B scenarios involving EDI communication.

Note: For detailed steps on setting up the AS2 adapter, refer to the blog: Step-by-Step Guide: Secure File Exchange with AS2 Adapter in SAP Cloud Integration â€“ SAP Community

Step 2: Add Start Message

Add a Start Message event to initiate the integration flow when EDI data is received through AS2.

Step 3: Add EDI Splitter

Add an EDI Splitter for handling incoming EDI messages. It breaks them down into individual transactions, checks their structure for validity, and can also generate acknowledgments if necessary.

Important:All the XSD and mapping files mentioned in this flow( ASC-X12 XSD, preproc.xsl, and others)â€”are created and exported during the MIG and MAG setup process in SAP Integration Advisor.
For a step-by-step guide on generating and exporting these files, please refer to the blog: Creating MIGs and MAGs Using Integration Advisor i... - SAP Community.

  • Upload ASC-X12 XSD File
  1. To upload ASC-X12 XSD file, navigate to the X12 tab in the EDI Splitter configuration. Youâ€™ll find the file in the Source folder that was extracted during the MAG export.
  2. This file outlines the structure of the incoming EDI message, allowing the splitter to accurately parse and process the X12 message.

Step 4: Add Router

Now, letâ€™s add a Router following the EDI Splitter. This step is crucial for separating EDI messages from acknowledgement messages, especially if youâ€™ve enabled the generation of acknowledgements in the splitter.

Let's define two routing paths:

1. Acknowledgement Route: This route deals with acknowledgement messages independently.

In the Processing tab, youâ€™ll see:

Expression Type Options:

  • XML: This is used when the message is formatted in XML.
  • NON_XML: This is for messages that arenâ€™t in XML format, where routing is based on the message headers.

We opt for NON_XML since the acknowledgement message isnâ€™t in XML, so the router checks the message headers instead of the XML content.

 Condition: ${header.EDI_ACKNOWLEDGEMENT} = 'true'

 

2. Default Route: Responsible for processing standard EDI messages.

No condition needed (processes all other messages)

Step 5: Integrate EDI to XML Converter

Now, letâ€™s add an EDI to XML Converter to convert the EDI message into XML format.

  • Upload ASC-X12 XSD File

  1. Navigate to the X12 tab and upload the ASC-X12.xsd file from the Source folder that you got from the MAG export.
  2. The ASC-X12 XSD file defines the structure of the incoming EDI message, enabling the EDI to XML Converter to accurately interpret and transform the EDI data into XML format.

Step 6: Include XSLT Mapping (Pre-processing)

Next up, weâ€™ll add XSLT Mapping to handle data preprocessing and transformation.

  • Upload preproc.xsl File
  1. Under the Processing tab, upload the preproc.xsl File from the Source folder extracted from the MAG export.
  2.  This step modifies the XML structure created from the EDI message, ensuring it aligns with the expected input format for message mapping.

Step 7: Add XML Validator (Post-processing)

Add an XML Validator to validate the pre-processed XML.

  • Upload X12_850_PurchaseOrder_MIG_RD.xsd File
  1. Navigate to the Validation tab and upload the X12_850_PurchaseOrder_MIG_RD.xsd file from the Source folder you extracted from the MAG export.
  2. This step makes sure that the transformed XML adheres to the expected schema before you proceed to message mapping, helping you identify any structural issues early on.

Step 8: Implement XSLT Mapping (Main Mapping)

Letâ€™s add an XSLT Mapping to transform the validated EDI XML into the target SOAP message structure.

  • Upload Mapping_X12_850_PurchaseOrder_MIG_to_SOAP_SalesOrder_MIG.xsl File

  1. Under the Processing tab, youâ€™ll need to upload the Mapping_X12_850_PurchaseOrder_MIG_to_SOAP_SalesOrder_MIG.xsl file from the root folder of the exported MAG zip file.
  2. This main mapping file, which was generated by SAP Integration Advisor (IA), is crucial for transforming the data into the right format for SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

Step 9: Apply XSLT Mapping (Post-processing)

Add an XSLT Mapping to adjust the mapped XML output to the final structure required by the target system.

  • Upload SOAP_SalesOrder_MIG_postproc.xsl File
  1. Head over to the Processing tab and upload the SOAP_SalesOrder_MIG_postproc.xsl file from the Target MIG folder.
  2. This ensures the transformed XML matches the exact format expected by the target system for successful processing.

Step 10: Add SOAP Receiver Adapter

Use the SOAP Receiver Adapter to connect to SAP S/4HANA and transmit the transformed XML payload over a SOAP-based web service. This adapter ensures that the data is encapsulated in a SOAP envelope and sent to the appropriate endpoint.

  • Address:Enter the SOAP service endpoint URL provided by your target system.

  • URL to WSDL:Click on Browse and upload the .wsdl file that corresponds to your target SOAP service. CPI will automatically fill in the Service, Endpoint, and Operation Name fields based on the WSDL information.
  • Authentication: Basic
  • Credential Name: Enter the Credential Name of the User Credentials you set up in Security Material.

This marks the end of the configuration for the EDI-to-SOAP inbound integration flow. With this iFlow in action, incoming EDI messages are handled efficiently and routed to the S/4HANA target system in the required SOAP format.
